bibl.title: Report: Prophylaxis and Serum Therapy of Yellow Fever, by Hideyo Noguchi, July 1921

div1.p: Noguchi's paper on prophylaxis and serum therapy of yellow fever. Discusses isolation of Leptospira icteroides, as well as experiments, efficacy of serum therapy of yellow fever and vaccination against yellow fever.

div1.head: Report:Prophylaxis and Serum Therapy of Yellow Fever," by Hideyo Noguchi, July 1921
div1.p:
Prophylaxis and Serum Therapy
of
Yellow Fever.
Hideyo Noguchi.
Journal A. M. A., July 1921.

This is easily the most important paper in yellow fever
literature that has appeared this year.

The writer begins by stating that Leptospira icteroides
has been isolated from yellow fever patients by Peres-Grovas
and by LeBlanc at Vera Cruz--he (Noguchi) recognizing the cul-
tures as identical with the other strains of the same organ-
ism: that Gastiaburú of Lima states that he has transmitted
the same infection to guinea pigs from cases occurring during
the epidemic in Piura and, finally, that the spirochete de-
monstrated in 1907 by Stimson of the U. S. Public Health Ser-
vice in a preperation stained by the Levaditi Method in the
kidney of a yellow fever patient dying in the New Orleans
epidemic of 1905 is identified by himself as Leptospira ic-
teroides.

He states that "the symptoms and lesions produced in ani-
mals by the inoculation of Leptospira icteroides “closely par-
allel those of human yellow fever and comprise mainly jaundice:
hemorrhages and intense acute nephritis.”

He admits that the guinea pig thus infected differ from
the man with yellow fever in the degree in which these general
lesions occur in the different tissues. In them hemorrhages
are much more marked in the lungs and serous surfaces of the
of the
2
stomach and intestines than in man. In puppies, however, hem-
orrhage into the lung substance is slight and that into the
gastro-intestinal tract (from its mucous membrane) gives the
“black vomit” and melena so characteristic of of yellow fever
in man.

That the reactions of guinea pigs and man differ even to
a considerable extent does not negative the possibilityclaim that
the toxins producing these reaction are from the same or-
ganism. Evidently the reactions of dogs and guinea pigs to
the same infection were quite different.

He further instances the specific immunity reactions for
Leptospira icteroides with serum of yellow fever convales-
cents in Guayaquil: Merida and Peru as contributing further
proof of the etiological relation of the organism. With this
the editor agrees.

He then discusses the therapeutic effect of an immune
(horse) serum (to Leptospira icteroides) on human yellow fev-
er patients. Animal experiment had shown that this serum was
efficacious in proportion to its early use, preventing the de-
velopement of the disease if given during the period of incu-
bation and favorably modifying it if given soon after its de-
velopement, but at a later stage it showed no beneficial ef-
fect.

He presents 170 patients treated by serum, 95 on or before
before
before
the 3rd. day
3
3
the 3rd. day and 75 after that time. Of the first, the mor-
tality was 13.6%: of the second, 52%, while the average mor-
tality of the epidemics in which these cases occurred was
56%.

Spite of this showing--and in spite also of the editor's
belief (from his observations in Peru) in the efficacy of the
serum used early--the data as assembled are not convincing.
The most that can be said of them is that they are very sug-
gestive and invite further trial. It may be that some data
on this subject will be added in Hanson's report of the epi-
demic in Peru of this year.
Vaccination against Yellow Fever.

Vaccination is by killed Cultures of Leptospira icteroides
given in two doses of 2 cc each subcutaneously. That furnished
us in Peru was given with an interval of from 5 to 8 days.
The culture medium contains a small amount of agar, difficult-
ly absorbable, and the seat of infection must be well massaged
for several minutes, else there may be severe reaction or even
a sterile abcess. Intro-muscular injection is not advised,
because the massage is apt to be less perfect.

A total of over 10,000 people had been vaccinated when
this article was written--and more since that time. It is
obviously innocuous, or at least fairly well borne. Now as
to its efficacy! What of the proportionate incidence of
yellow fever among the vaccinated and the unvaccinated, other
4
other
conditions being the same?

In the first place, he considers this incidence in two groups:
(a) Those in which the fever developes within 10 days from
the time of last inoculation and (b) Those in whom it takes
place “one month or longer” after vaccination.

He has a perfect right to make this division and to claim
that the vaccination is not protective until after ten days
have passed from the 2nd. dose--which his figures bear out--
but to base this claim on an incubation period for yellow fever
of 12 days, “experimentally established by the French Commis-
sion in Brazil,” is not only unnecessary, but is to use a
most insecure foundation. His claim is that such cases as de-
velope within 10 days, and they seem to have been fairly nu-
merous, were contracted and were in the incubative stage prior
to the vaccination. Yet of 43 cases of yellow fever, some ex-
perimental and some with a single short exposure of a few hours,
of which the period of incubation was carefully observed, the
longest was 6 days and 2 hours. And I think that these are the
only cases, naturally acquired, the incubation periods of which
are accepted by sanitarians.

Not considering the (a) class of cases the author seems to
make a very good showing for the protective value of vaccina-
tion. His data, however, need, and will repay, examination.
The difficulty under the present conditions of yellow fever work
of obtaining data both reliable and determinative has been ex-
treme, and if that here presented does not completely fill both
5
both
conditions, it is not to be wondered at.

Some of it strongly evidences the protective value of the
vaccination. Thus: Tuxpan--2,000 vaccinated--

Tuxpan--2,000 vaccinated;--- 17 cases, class (a)-- 0-class (b)
4,000 unvaccinated:---------- 85 cases.

Los Amates, 660 population: 12 cases June 6th.--Aug. 12th.
600 vaccinated, Aug. 20-30---2 cases class (a)--0 class (b)
39 unvaccinated--------------- 1 case Sept. 31.

The remainder 38 vaccinated Sept. 31st. gave no further
cases.

Nothing is said as to whether other measures of control of the
fever were adopted at this last place or no. I presume that if they
had been it had been mentioned. This would not seem to have been
even a possible factor in the result at Tuxpan as 85 cases oc-
curred among the unvaccinated as compared with 34--the number
which would have occurred in the same number of vaccinated. For
a comparison, however, we must assume that such conditions of
life as involve liability to control yellow fever other than
the vaccination were approximately the same in the two groups.
A greater difference than this existed in different sections of
New Orleans in 1897.

Unless then there was a considerable difference in the above
mentioned conditions of life protective to the vaccinated
group, the difference in the rate of incidence is too great to
allow other interpretation from these statistics than that a
marked protection was given by the vaccination. We wish more
detail had been given of this epidemic in Tuxpan.
Tuxpan.

The data from Quirigua: Puerto Barrios: Virginia and Tambo
Grande are not illuminating: Nor is that from Salvador.

For Guayaquil we have much fuller data--thanks to a pre-
vious paper of Noguchi and Pareja:

In October 1918, the batallion of Vincedores--327 men--coming
from Quito to Guayaquil, were vaccinated--149 with Vaccine A,
and 178 with Vaccine B--very much weaker. The reason for us-
ing Vaccine B was because there was not enough of Vaccine A to
go around than so less had to be used for the last part of the
batallion. This vaccine was not nearly as potent as that now
used, the proportion being as 1 to 1,000.

These men, presumably all susceptible to yellow fever,
were stationed in barracks in Guayaquil in which there had
occurred 58 cases: 29 deaths, among 300 soldiers in the six
months to June 1918. “Owing to sanitary measures at and a-
round the barracks,” only one death--nothing is said of cases--
occurred from July to October. So much from the paper mention-
ed.

In the paper under review, Noguchi states that from this
group of 427 vaccinated, there were 6 cases of yellow fever--
1, class (a)----and-----5. class (b)---none of these were a-
mong the 149 vaccinated with Vaccine A.

Among the civil population susceptible to Yellow Fever, estimated by him at 3,573, be-
tween October 1918 and March 1919: 386 cases of fever occurred--
Counting, as I think we must, the case in class (a), the pro-
pro
pro-

portion is 1 to 8.

Admitting that these men were confined to barracks as
much as possible, by order and by counsel: that, in the begin-
ning at least, they would be afraid to go into the infected
city: that the barracks themselves were safe--as is shown by
their being practically free from fever for the previous four
months: yet this disproportion of infection testifies very
strongly to a decided protection from vaccination. It seems
too great to be explained away. Accepting these figures, no
other interpretation seems reasonable. If only the Vince-
dores had been vaccinated with the full dose, A, as far as it
would have gone and left a portion of them--140--as a Control
we might have had absolutely definite, reliable data deter-
mining the value of this vaccine for men as it is determined
for animals!

The editor, while in Peru in 1920 and the early part of
this year, pressed the use of vaccine-- of which he received
from Dr. Noguchi at first a small, and afterwards a much larger,
lot. He used it at first for sanitary workers and physicians
going into the epidemic and later as we use the similar method
in the control of small-pox. He, at this time, based his ad-
vocacy of the vaccine solely on the result of animal experi-
mentation. Had he known of the results of the Guayaquil vac-
cination--that at Tuxpan had not yet been done--he had been
even more zealous than he was. He used the vaccination and ad-
ad-

vised its use in the sanitary campaign solely as an adjuvant,
the method depended on being the control of Stegomyia
breeding. That it can become a valuable adjuvant he fully
believes, especially in small places. It is clearly of es-
pecial value in places which can free themselves from yellow
fever by “failure of the human host,” it hastening that process
in proportion to the extent used. For such places we should be able
